question: Which of the following present with loss of consciousness:
exp: Ans. (d) Organic brain syndrome. ORGANIC BRAIN SYNDROME* It is also known as organic brain disease which is decreased mental function due to a medical disease, other than a psychiatric illness.* Cognitive or higher mental functions (i. e. consciousness, orientation & abstract thinking) are impaired in organic brain syndrome.

question: All are affected in dementia except -
exp: Ans. is 'a' i. e., Consciousness o Dementia is a progressive generalized impairment of intellectual functions and memory without impairment of consciousness. o Dementia is a chronic organic mental disorder causing disturbances of higher cortical functions (Cortical dementia), except in subcortical dementias. Dementias are characterized by:-1) Impairment of memory:- Memory functions are mostly affected. Recent memory is affected at first with difficulty to learn new material. Later even remote memory is affected. Confabulation is common. 2) Impairment of intellectualfunction:- Disorientation (particularly to time), impaired attention & concentration. 3) Impairementt of thinking and judgement:- Thinking becomes slower and abstract thinking may be impaired. Delusions and paranoid thoughts may develop. 4) Deterioration of personality and personal care - The patient becomes solvently in dress and demenour. Clothes become unkempt and stained and are not worn properly. 5) Impairment of language:- There is difficulty in word finding and a reduced functional vocabulary in speech. Perseveration and echolalia can occur. 6) Catastrophic reactions:- Some people with dementia overreact to a trivial setback or a minor criticism. This might involve them screaming, shouting, making unreasonable accusations, becoming very agitated or stubborn, or crying or laughing uncontrollably and inappropriately. o Characteristically there is no impairment of consciousness.

question: Clouding of consciousness is seen in:
exp: Ans. (b) Delirium. Ref.: Harrison 19th ed. /166. DELIRIUM* It is characterized by global impairment of consciousness (clouding of consciousness), resulting in reduced levels of alertness, attention & perception of environment along with acute onset of fluctuating cognitive impairment.* It is the commonest organic mental disorder. Clinical Features & Diagnosis* Global impairment of consciousness & attention is the hallmark/cardinal feature of Delirium. It manifests as:# Diminished ability to focus, sustain or shift attention.# Reduced levels of alertness, attention, and perception of environment.# Drowsiness (mental slowness), distractibility & disorientation.* Global impairment of cognition is manifested as:# Disorientation (in time, place and person)# Disturbance of immediate & recent memory# Remote memory is intact.

question: Reversible dementia is a feature of:
exp: Ans: D (Hypothyroidism) Ref: Harrison 's Textbook of Internal Medicine. Explanation. Dementia. It is a syndrome characterized by. Memory disturbances (typically acquisition & recent memory are impaired). Agnosia (inability to recognise like one's name). Aphasia (inability to talk properly). Apraxia (inability to do which were done with ease before). Executive dysfunction (unable to perform the previously performed. dearned activities). Dementia is basically due to degeneration of neurons of brain. Depending upon the site, it may be cortical (Alzheimer's disease) or subcortical (Parkinson's disease) or mixed (Vascular/Multi-infarct dementia). While the degeneration is progressive, sometimes if the cause is removed or treated, the dementia resolves. Hence, depending upon the "reversibility", there are1. Irreversible dementias (Alzheimer's disease. Multi-infarct dementia)2. Reversible [FEDUP|Failure of other organs (CCF, CO PD Respirator}' failure. Renal failure, etc.).
